scenes.location: NEW YORK CITY/INT. NYC TAXI AS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman stands in front of a bathroom mirror, curling her hair. Her name is SALLY HOLLAR, 58. Sally is dressed in a pink nightgown and robe. She is a kind looking woman. Heavy set and motherly with lines of distinction on her face. She takes a breath and faces herself in the mirror. A troubled look flutters across her eyes. An out of shape man opens the door to the bathroom. His name is RON HOLLAR, 36. Ron is Sally’s son. He looks surprised to see his mother there.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry. I thought you were...gone. Sally looks annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Ronald. This is my bathroom. If you're going to stay here, you have to use the downstairs bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Dad’s in that one.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Well, then you’re going to have to wait. Ron goes to leave... then comes back.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: How long?--

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Close the door. Sally picks up her curling iron. INT. KITCHEN, HOLLAR HOUSE. DAY. Ron holds himself as he looks around the kitchen. He takes a container for juice out of a cupboard and pees into it. A look of relief comes across his face as he urinates into the container.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? Ron jumps, almost spilling everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Jesus, Dad, you scared me! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron looks over his shoulder at his father, DONALD HOLLAR, 62, staring at him. Don is a taller, angry looking man. He is dressed in flannel pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Your mother puts orange juice in that thing. Ron can’t stop peeing.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m going to wash it. Don looks upset. But before he can say anything else Sally screams in the bathroom. Glass breaks. Don and Ron give each other a look. INT. BATHROOM, HOLLAR HOUSE. DAY. Ron and Don find Sally shaking on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (totally confused) Sally! What-- What are you doing on the floor?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What do you mean you don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I think I’m having a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: A stroke?! You’re only fifty eight.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Dad! The curling iron! The curling iron is burning her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Get up, chief.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I can’t. I can’t move. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron goes over to his mother and moves the curling iron away from her. Her wrist is badly burnt.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. Don stares in terror. He doesn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, call an ambulance! Don doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (screams ) Dad, call an ambulance! Now! Don stands still. Ron gets up and runs out. We stay on Don, lost. Then off camera we hear...

dialogues.speaker: RON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? Hello? INT. OFFICE CUBICLE, NEW YORK CITY. DAY. THE SAME MUSIC CUE FROM THE LAST SCENE CONTINUES as we come in on a man, 34, sitting at a cubicle talking on the phone. He is of average height and weight. He has a common face with a good natured grin. He wears a blue oxford with the sleeves rolled up to his elbows and dark grey slacks. His name is John Hollar. Hanging on the cubicle walls are a few pictures of him with his girlfriend and many, many comic book-esque drawings. John wears a head set as he seemingly draws something. Suddenly the music stops. We hear a very southern voice.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Speaking into head set) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about the wait.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh... that’s no problem. I was actually... kind of enjoying being on hold. What music was that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The hold music? I have no idea. We don’t have access to that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You don’t have access to music?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, we don’t have anything to do with programming the hold music. Someone else does that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How do you get that job?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is there something I can help you with?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Uh, yes. Yes. This is John Hollar. No response.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From Routlege Publishing?...We spoke last week. There is no answer. John looks for an invoice number on his desk. As he turns we see what he’s been drawing... A bizarre cartoon of a baby in an ultra sound photo. The baby looks angrily out at John with a word bubble above it’s head. “Oh, great!”

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I’m calling about order number 6849-49-494-8464-9494-8602.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s the last part?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No! The part before that!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You found it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I said “Uh huh”!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh ok, can you just tell me, is that order finished? Because it was scheduled to be at our interior printer yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, that order is not finished.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s not... Well, can I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Because... I guess I forgot to put it through. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You forgot to put it through? I see. Hmmm. But you didn’t forget to send us an invoice?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I said I was sorry! I’m the only person in this department. And I’ve only been here three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, no. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s hard to keep everything straight all the time, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yes, it is hard to keep things straight all the time.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look, you don’t need to talk down to me. I only took this goddamn job cuz I got fired from my last one for being late!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, geez, I’m sorry I didn’t realize that-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They didn’t care that my boyfriend was dumping me that morning!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh God, I’m so sorry I-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, we were havin’ breakfast and he just stood up! Like some kinda zombie. I looked up and asked him what was wrong and he said... (She begins to cry) Youuuuu....

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No, no. Please don’t-- What was your name again? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nancyyyy---

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nancy, please don’t cry. Please don’t do that. It’s okay. Listen, we all have stuff, right?... I mean, hey, if it makes you feel any better, I think I’m in the middle of a some kind of life crisis myself.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -.. Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh God yeah! Are you kidding? I’m anxious, like, all the time. I have no idea what I’m doing with my life. I mean, for starters what is this job? Am I right? Do you even know what we do? Of course not. But it’s funny how little money it takes to give up on a dream isn’t it? I thought I was an artist. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Um... I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, I’m sorry! About your boyfriend. I have a girlfriend who I don’t deserve. She’s beautiful and smart and runs her own company. We’ve been together for 3 years! She’s amazing! But, that doesn’t stop my insane brain from consistently questioning and over analyzing our relationship. I’m sure that’s fun for her. Oh and did I mention she’s eight months pregnant??? You have kids?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, lemme tell ya, nothing holds your life up to a big mirror like a due date. I don’t know what’s wrong with me. Every day, I’m feeling more and more lost and inadequate. And the craziest part I can’t get out of my head is... “Did I ever even really want a kid ANYWAY" ???2?22?2” John is in a state. Pause. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +. I’m sorry I didn’t put the order through.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, that’s...hey, you’ll get em to us when you get em to us, right?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Boy or girl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh we don’t-- We want it to be a surprise. We want everything to be a surprise... You, uh... you have a nice day, Nancy. John hangs up the phone and stares at the drawing. He then picks it up and holds it next to an actual ultra sound image that is taped to his computer. He just stares. The phone rings. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Routledge Publishing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nancy?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, Rebecca. I’m sorry I missed the appointment. I just got swamped. How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: It was... fine. We can talk about it another time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ok. Can I call you back in a little bit, I’m in the middle of a-- An extremely pregnant woman on a cellphone rounds the corner of John’s cubicle. It is John’s girlfriend, Rebbecca Feingold, 31.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey! How’d you get up here? You need a card to--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: John, listen. Your Dad called me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Your Mom had a seizure this morning. They think it might be a brain tumor. I booked you on a non stop flight, so you should get in around 3:30. I packed you clothes and some lunch in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: There are non-stop flights to--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: John, this is serious. Your dad called the house. He was sobbing into the phone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who thinks it might be a brain tumor? John just looks at Rebecca. A new experience of anxiety washes over his face. He is either not getting it, or not accepting it. It’s hard to tell.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I know this is a lot. But, your mother is in the hospital. You have to go. Now. Rebecca rolls John’s suitcase closer to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This snaps John out of it. *

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Wait, you’re not going to come with me? *

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: They won’t let me on a plane like this.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, I can’t-- I can’t just leave you here. Rebecca gives John a long, hard look.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: John, it’s your mother. You need to go. We'll figure everything else out later.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you mean figure everything else out?

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: She needs you. * The weight of this statement hits John for the first time. He looks really scared.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Okay. I should tell Mike about missing * work-- *

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: I'll go find Mike. You just go get a * cab. Call me when you get there. * John stands. He takes the bag from Rebecca. She gives him a big hug. They smile warmly at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John exits his work building and drives to airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John arrives at JFK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John rides along a people mover as people pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Delta plane takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits in his seat on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John deplanes down the jetway and walks into small town terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John exits the gate area in his hometown airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John walks out of the airport and into the street. He hails a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits in the taxi and stares out the window at a lone highway of strip malls, GAPS and APPLEBEES.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to the taxi driver) Can we stop at a gas station for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stands at the edge of the gas station and smokes a cigarette. He hasn’t smoked in a long time and it shows. He doesn’t look right holding it. But he’s happy to have the nicotine running through his blood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John watches as high school kids exit the gas station with ‘slushies’ and cigarettes. John stares at the former version of himself. The taxi driver sits in his car and sighs with boredom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally lies in bed, knitting, as she watches Project Runway. She is in a hospital gown but otherwise she seems fine. Don and Ron sit beside Sally. They watch the show as well. There is a nurse changing Sally’s IV.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s really creative. I would have never thought to do that with denim.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: He wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh, I would. I think that’s terrific. INT. HOSPITAL HALLWAY. DAY. Al10 John walks down the hospital hallway and pauses just before entering his Mom’s room. He takes a breath... then walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, mom. Sally lights up when she sees him.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh my God--Look who’s here! How did you know? John looks to his Dad who smiles. SALLY (CONT’D) Donald! Don gives a satisfied laugh as he hugs his son.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come here and give mom a hug. John puts down his bag and gives his mother a big hug. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How you doing? John looks at her wrist. It is all bandaged up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Brain tumor. Have you been smoking?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? No? John pats his brother on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You smell like an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Don’t lie to your mother. She almost died today.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: She didn’t almost die.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: That’s not what the doctor said.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That wasn’t a doctor. He was a nurse. We haven’t seen a doctor yet. And you’re scaring mom.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I’m not scared. I just don’t want John to get lung cancer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to his mother) I only had one.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Well, don’t have anymore. You're going to be a father soon.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I know. I know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: That guy was a nurse?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. He was in John’s class in high school.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really? What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Jason.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Jason? Jason Owens?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Wow, he’s a nurse? That guy was such a burn out in high school.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I thought he was nice.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: He married Gwen. John is a bit taken aback by this information.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (surprised) She married Jason Owens?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: She just had a kid.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Are you serious? How did I not know that? Ron shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Who's Gwen?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Surprised, but polite) Oh, you know Gwen. Johnny’s girlfriend in high school. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ron nods. 13.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (can’t believe his father doesn’t remember) They were engaged for God’s sake!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: John had a girlfriend in high school?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It was complicated.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Dad. Where you been our whole lives anyway?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Working my ass off so you kids could go to college. That’s where I’ve been.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Yeah. A lot of good that did.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to himself) Gwen married Jason Owens?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (To John) Just had a kid.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: No, tell me what you just said.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (To Don) I didn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You better watch yourself, boy.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh, is that a threat?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: No. It’s a promise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That doesn’t even make sense.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I‘1l punch you in the face.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (laughs ) What?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I swear to God, I will.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, what's stopping-- Don slaps Ron hard in the face.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ow! Man!

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Donald!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That hurt.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Dad. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Donald! Apologize to Ron right now! Don looks very remorseful for what he’s just done. He puts his hand on Ron’s back.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Ron. I didn’t mean to-- Ron slaps his father.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Asshole. Don and Ron get into a pretty serious slap fight. John tries to break up the fight.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Guys! Guys, stop! Suddenly Sally just slightly raises her hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (Quietly) Boys. The boys immediately calm down as a quiet Asian man enters the room holding a medical chart. His name is DR. LARRY FONG, 40. Everyone turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: (to Sally) Sally Hollar?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: I’m Doctor Fong. Sorry about the wait. (beat) I was golfing.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: No problem, Doctor. Dr. Fong brings up a cat scan image on a monitor on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: I looked over your cat scans. You have a pretty big brain tumor in the center of your frontal lobe.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ. Oh, Jesus Christ. Don sits down on a chair. He starts trembling. He is way overdoing this. Sally tries to keep a smile on her face but she looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Pretty big? Dr. Fong gives John a serious look.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: It means...big.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So, what do we have to do?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: We're going to have to remove it. Soon. I’ve scheduled a craniotomy for the end of next week. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Wait. Slow down. What about a second opinion?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: You're free to do as you wish. But I suggest you do it quickly. We can give your mother steroids to reduce the size of the tumor. But the seizures will continue if nothings done.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Now, what will the steroids do to her muscles? Will it make her bulky?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: (a little confused) No.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ. Oh, christ. Oh, christ.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Get a grip, Dad. Don is not good in a crisis. Sally has a nervous smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, is it...cancer?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: We won’t know that until we biopsy a piece of the tumor.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. How did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: It could be any number of reasons. We have no way of knowing right now. I will say this, it’s not a young tumor. I'd say it’s most likely been growing inside Mrs. Hollar’s head for over ten, maybe fifteen years. To be honest I’m surprised there haven’t been more symptoms. Don looks very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Would loss of sight in one eye be a symptom? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Possibly.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: How about a numbness in the toes and fingers?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: And temporary paralysis?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Well, definitely.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I told you!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: She might have had some symptoms before today.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? When? Why didn’t you have them checked out?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: He sent me to Jenny Craig.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I thought it was a weight thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, Dad. Temporary paralysis?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Dad!

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Yes, well. You guys seem like you have some stuff to work out so... Dr. Fong tries to quietly leave the room. John stops him in the hallway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Wait, doctor. Tell me seriously, how bad is this?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: She has a tumor the size of a softball in her head.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, is it terminal?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. We won't know until we get in there to remove the tumor.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Honestly? John nods. Dr. Fong looks into Sally’s room at Don and Ron.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd try to keep them away from her as much as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron drives on the way home from the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s up with you and dad?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He seems really pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Doesn’t he always?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not like that. Ron takes a breath. He doesn’t know if he should tell John this or not...

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: He fired me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ron parks 19. 10

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He fired you? I didn’t even know you were working for him.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You should really call more.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t like to talk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m on Facebook.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. I put it on my status update last week.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So, what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, why did he let you go?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: The business has been operating at a loss for over a year. Dad’s about three weeks away from total bankruptcy. When I confronted him about it he fired me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Are you kidding me??

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don’t say anything. He made me promise not to tell anyone. I’m sure he doesn’t want mom to worry about it right now. in front of a house. He keeps the car running.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, what is he going to do?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He and mom don’t have any savings. The medical bills are going to be crazy. They’re totally screwed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Oh my God. Ron reaches across John to the glove box... and pulls a pair of binoculars out. He begins to surveil the house he’s just parked in front of.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: How’s Rebecca?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (puzzled) She’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Mom said things haven’t been great. Is that why you’re not going to get married?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How would she possibly kn--

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Do you think your kid will mind being a bastard?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Uh, people don’t really think like that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Yeah, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Stacey started seeing someone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You've been divorced from Stacey for years.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I agreed to a divorce. I didn’t agree to some strange man hanging around my daughters. A man comes to the front window of the house.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit! Get down! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ron and John get down in their seats. The man steps out of the house and walks towards the car. He walks over to Ron’s window and taps. Ron rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Ron. How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You two know each other?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. He’s the new youth pastor over at mom and dad’s church.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Reverend Dan, nice to meet you. Reverend Dan extends his hand to John. John shakes it. He is a very warm and congenial man with a thing for plaid shirts.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: John Hollar.

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: I heard about your mother. I’m very sorry. How is she?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (bitter) She’s fine. No thanks to you. John and Dan look puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on, Ron. He didn’t have anything to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: How do you know? He’s supposed to talk to God, isn’t he? Maybe he put in an order for a brain tumor or something. Reverend Dan smiles good naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: I’m afraid it doesn’t work like that, Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. How does it work, Reverend Dan? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dan looks Pause. Ron tries 22.

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: I’m just a youth pastor.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, couldn’t get a job as an adult pastor?

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: No. I just...like kids.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well...that’s creepy. at the binoculars in Ron’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, look, Ron, I know you’re going through a hard time and everything but Stacey asked if you could maybe...stop parking in front of the house and staring at her with your binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Is that what she asked?

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: The girls still up?

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: Yes, but we’re having dinner right now. And I don’t think it would be that great for them to see you like this.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... Fuck you, Reverend Dan! to peel out but the engine dies when he presses down on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: REV. DAN
dialogues.text: Sounded like a broken t-chain. I can take a look for you if you want. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ron looks at John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me. I don’t know anything about cars.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (to Dan, still angry) That would be really helpful. Thanks. All EXT. HOLLAR HOUSE. DAY. All Ron and John drive up. John looks up at his childhood home for the first time in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Ron walk into the front hall. John puts down his bag and looks around, this once familiar world now feeling completely alien.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You can have our old room. I’m in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What, you live here now?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: We're in a recession. John shakes his head. He can’t believe how much he doesn’t know about his family. He starts up the stairs to his old room. Al2 INT. HOLLAR HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY. Al2 As John walks down the hallway to his old room, he looks at old family photos that line the walls. 12 INT. JOHN’S ROOM, HOLLAR HOUSE. LATE DAY. 12 John walks into his room, a bed on either side. On one side it is plastered with original drawings, cartoons, and funny portraits of semi-celebrities like Bea Arthur and the bearded guy from Highway to Heaven. The other side is covered in music posters from Metallica to Lynyrd Skynrd. John looks around wistfully. He unpacks his bag and then suddenly stops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the bag we see what looks like a nicely bound journal, along with a note. The note reads, “Maybe you’ll get some ideas for this while you’re home. Love, Becca.” He opens up the journal and flips through one third of a beautifully drawn graphic novel. We recognize the lead character from some of the drawings hanging in John’s cubicle. He throws the book on the bed and looks out the window... EXT. HOLLAR HOUSE. LATE DAY. Al3 From outside the house we see John looking out the window of the bedroom he lived in for 18 years. Suddenly, we see a few neighborhood kids run by playing “Kick the Can”. John notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John walks to the open door of his mother’s hospital room. He finds his mother and father sleeping. His mother sleeps on the hospital bed and his father sleeps on a chair next to her. They hold hands. John looks very touched by the sight of his parents together in this way. He quietly walks over to his father and puts his hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (whispers ) Dad. Dad. Don wakes. He groggily turns to John.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Eight o’ clock.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Shit. Shit! I got to get to work. Shit. Shit! Don gets up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's ok. I brought your briefcase. I put it in your truck. Don takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I got you a coffee. John hands his dad a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No problem. Just go to work. I’1l stay with mom.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’1l call if there’s any news. Don looks at Sally. He starts to tear up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad? (beat) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I just don’t know what I’1l do if I lose her. Don starts to sob. John gives his father a hug.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey. Don’t talk like that. It’s all going to work out fine. You'll see. Don sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go to work.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Okay. Don puts his hand on his son's face.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re a good boy. He smiles and leaves the room. After a beat...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Alright, he’s gone. You can stop pretending.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Thank god. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: He cried all night. If I didn’t know any better I’d think he was the one with the tumor.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I think he’s feeling a lot of pressure right now.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Ron told you we’re about to go bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He said it was a secret.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I keep the books.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s going to happen?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I brought you pretzels and ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’s breakfast time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? You don’t want any?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that. John smiles. He prepares a bowl of vanilla ice cream and pretzel sticks for his mom. He covers it in chocolate sauce.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So. Are you feeling okay?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I feel great.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nothing weird during the night? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You mean besides your father’s sobbing?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I googled brain tumors. They’re a lot more common than you’d think.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Bob Marley had one.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Really? How did that work out for him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Uh...you know. He sold a lot of records.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You're going to get through this. Don’t worry. (beat) The actual procedure sounds pretty simple. They just cut open a little hole the size of a nickel in your skull and take out the--

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to upset you-

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (smiles) I’m not upset.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You're shaking.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’s cold in here.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, look, Mom, it’s okay to be scared.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I’m not scared. How’s Rebecca? A male nurse walks into the room. It is John’s old high school classmate, Jason Owens, 32. Jason watches Sally eat her ice cream and pretzels with a frown on his face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: What’s this? Ice cream for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, hey. Yeah. Ice cream and pretzels, actually. It’s one of my mom’s favorites.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? How about heart attacks? Does she like those, too?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Your mom’s a borderline diabetic.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really? Sally nods. Jason takes the bowl of ice cream from Sally and hands her a tray with an egg and a piece of toast on it.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Believe it or not we keep our patients on a strict diet for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I just wanted to give her a little something.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Yeah, well, next time try a greeting card. They’ve actually become a lot more sophisticated in the past couple years. You can almost always find one to match the exact sentiment you’re going for.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do you have a problem with me or something? Jason looks very unhappy. He takes a deep breath and walks out of the room. He nods for John to follow. John looks confused. He follows Jason out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason holds the bowl of ice cream and pretzels. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John takes 29. 14

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What is it? What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Gwen’s been asking about you ever since she heard your mom was here.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. I heard you guys were--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (defiantly) Married. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: --Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She just had a kid.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I... heard that too. Congratulations to both of you--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Cut the bullshit. Are you going to try anything? a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, look, man. I got a girlfriend back in New York. We’re actually about to have a baby too, so--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You’re not married?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Why not? You're going to have a kid together.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s... a long story. We’ve talked about it but-- what do you care?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Don’t you think your child might resent you for making it a bastard? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The kid’s not going to be a bastard!

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Well, no, technically it will.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Look, the point is you got nothing to worry about. Gwen and I are way, way in the past. We haven’t talked in years.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She still looks great, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: -..-I’m sure she does but--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Great! Alt] Maybe better! [ ] May:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Look, I have no feelings for Gwen anymore. Haven't for a very long time. I’m not going to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Positive.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Okay. Good. In that case I’m supposed to invite you over to the house for dinner tomorrow. We just had a new deck built. It's really nice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s great. Jason takes a bite of the ice cream and pretzels.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: This is good.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m glad you like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron sits in his car and waits down the road from the same house he was stalking last night. He stays low in his seat. After a moment, two girls come out of the house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Their names are Constance, 9, and Matilda, 6. They are followed by a woman. The girls’ mother, Stacey, 38. She gives each child a kiss goodbye and then the girls walk towards school. Ron waits for Stacey to go back in the house, then he starts his car and follows the girls down the street. Ron pulls up to the girls. He rolls down his window.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh. Hey there. What are you cool girls doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad. Walking to school.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, wow, that’s so random. You want a ride? The girls look at each other. They think about it for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both girls sit in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So, how you guys doing? The girls do not respond.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Mom said that we can’t see you until they review your behavior in 3 months.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Who’s they?

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA
dialogues.text: Mommy’s lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What? My behavior?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: They need to see you have a steady job.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That’s just-- that’s. Anyway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beat. 32. 16 RON (CONT’D) Yeah? Do anything fun last night?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No? Did you...see Reverend Dan?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So, what’s his story anyway? Seems kind of like a creep to me.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Do you like him?

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA
dialogues.text: He’s a really good dancer.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (disturbed) He dances for you? Constance gives her sister an angry look.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: He bought us Dance, Dance, Revolution.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (bruised) Oh. Wow. That’s cool. You’ve been wanting that for awhile, right?

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA
dialogues.text: You should come over and play it with us sometime.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah, Yeah. Maybe I will. (beat) You know your grandmother has a brain tumor.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Mom told us. How is she?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: She’s probably going to die. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: What? I thought mom said it was too soon to say.

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA
dialogues.text: (emotional) What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No. It’s for sure. She’s going to die.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god.

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA
dialogues.text: Grandma's going to die?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You girls want to come see her at the hospital with me? The girls look at each other. The oldest one is still skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It might be your last chance. (beat) I'll take you to Wal-Mart after. The girls don’t go for it.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chuck-E-Cheese? The girls smile. EXT. HOLLAR HEATING AND PLUMBING SUPPLIES. MORNING. Al7 Don enters his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don walks into his small manufacturing plant. An unhappy woman sits at the front desk of a small office space.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Hey. Where is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Not here.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Where are they? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Called in sick.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Everyone?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: I'm guessing it might have something to do with not getting paid in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Well, don’t they know about Sally???

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, guilting people into free labor only works on family members.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I wish I had more sisters. Beat. Pam looks at Don.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: How’s she doing, Donny?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: --.-I don’t know. She was sleeping when I left. I should go back and check on her.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: I’ll go check on her. You need to get to work. We got an order in this morning. Don pulls his wallet out. He takes out a credit card. He hands it to Pam.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Here. Take this. Use it to pay everyone for the last week.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Can you afford that?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Do it anyway. And then tell them to get their asses back to work. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: How about you? How are you doing for money?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Carl was laid off.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Alright, keep the card. Just... only use it for what you absolutely need. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (trying to make Don laugh) Carl thinks I need a boob job. Don considers.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Oh, geez, I don’t know Pam. Pam’s face falls as she goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally and John sit silently in the hospital room. Sally smiles at John. John smiles back. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: So how are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m fine, Mom. I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You’re a terrible liar. SALLY (CONT’D) How's your job?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, soul crushing. It continually forces me to question the purpose of my existence.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I wish Ron could find something. He’s so lost. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beat. 36. 18

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: And what about your cartoon story?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s not called a cartoon story, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m sorry. What’s it called?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A graphic novel.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Rebecca sent me some of it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ++. She did?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: She says she thinks you should try to get it published.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, because... it’s not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I like Rebecca... She’s pushy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Men need to be pushed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, Mom. Let’s face it. I made a mistake. I’m not an artist.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You know just after your Father and I first met we lived in Detroit. Only about a year. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He worked in a small office downtown and I would pick him up every day. I don’t think he never knew why... His office was right by the Fox theatre. It was built in the 1920's as a movie theater. The first movie theater in the world to be built with speakers for sound movies. Your dad would get off work at 5... and I'd leave our apartment at 3 and walk down to the Fox. There was never a show at that time. And I‘d go in. And I would sit ina seat... And I’d look up at the ceiling. It was unlike anything I’d ever seen with its beautiful design and colors. And this enormous chandelier. It was made from 1200 pieces of glass. It was breathtaking... And every day I’d go back. I’d go in. And I’d look up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You never told me that.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I never really had a chance to pursue anything creative. I got married so young to your father and then Ronnie came along.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do you ever wish you’d...done things differently?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (without hesitation) Oh, yeah. Big time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Definitely. Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not sure it was a good idea to Marry your father.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John looks stunned by what his mother has just said. But before he can ask anything else Ron and his girls come into the room. Ron holds Matilda’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Look who I found!

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Grandma! The girls run to Sally and give her big, clutching hugs.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Girls! What are you doing out of school?

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA
dialogues.text: (crying) I don’t want you to die, Grandma! Sally and John look at Ron. He holds a bag in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: We brought you pretzels and ice cream. Constance looks at Sally’s cat scans on the wall monitor.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Is that your tumor? John looks out at this scene and, still taken aback from the conversation with his mom, walks to the door of the hospital room.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey. I’m going to go for a little drive. You need anything?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind a bag of Doritos.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I was talking to mom.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: No. I’m good, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John exits the hospital and sees his Aunt Pam walking up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aunt Pam!

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Hey, Johnny. You look great.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You’re a terrible liar.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: How’s Mom doing?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She’s good... Weirdly.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: She’s a tough broad. I never worry about her... You’re dad, I always worry about.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah... How’s the business doing?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Not great. At this point it’s just about keeping up the facade. But, you’d know all about that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Get your dad to hire your brother back.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?! What good could possibly come of that?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Well, first of all we won’t have to pay him right away. Second, he’s the best salesman we've had.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ron?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: I didn't say I understand it. I’m just telling you how it is. Your brother is the Rain Man of local plumbing sales.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Then why did Dad fire him? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: That’s family, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca stands in a makeshift studio filled with toy dogs in sweaters as a photographer takes their pictures. Her cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh thank God, it’s so good to hear your voice. John takes cigarette out of his pocket and lights it while he drives, talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: John? Hi! How are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not so good.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, my mom has a tumor the size of a softball in her head. They don’t know if it’s cancerous or not. The doctor wants to perform a craniotomy the end of the week. That’s where they take out the tumor. My dad’s about to lose his business. Mom says she thinks she regrets marrying him. My brother is living at home and stalking his ex-wife. And on top of everything else my mom’s nurse hates me.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What? Why does your mom’s nurse hate you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s just this guy. We used to go to high school together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What’s his problem?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing. I don’t know. He’s...married to Gwen.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Gwen? Gwen, Gwen? Like...your Gwen?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, she’s not my Gwen anymore.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Oh...wow.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Anyway, he’s really insecure. He still thinks Gwen has a thing for me. (pause) Isn’t that crazy? Rebecca’s face changes.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Crazy...Are you going to see her?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? I don’t know. I hadn’t really thought about it. I mean, maybe. They did invite me over for dinner. Rebecca doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, don’t worry! Nothing’s gonna happen. I don’t feel anything for her anymore. I mean she just had a kid.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Wow... That’s an incredibly insensitive thing to say to me right now. John takes a drag of his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No! I didn’t mean--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: What is that sound? Are you smoking?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (meekly) Kind of. Yeah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: John... you don’t smoke. Just throw it away and... call me later ok?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Rebecca, I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to--

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: It’s ok, John. I have to get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I was calling to tell you how excited I was to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: And I’m glad you did. We’1ll talk later, ok?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John drive s through rural landscape. It’s all cornfields and old farm houses. He stops and turns off onto a little dirt road. EXT. POND. John pulls the water. and lights

dialogues.speaker: DAY. 25
dialogues.text: up to a swimming hole with a tire swing over He walks to the water, takes out a cigarette it. He stares wistfully at the little swimming hole. He decides to hang on the swing. He grabs the swing and gets on. He smiles as he swings above the water smoking hi s cigarette. It reminds him of being a teenager. But before the moment can last too long the tree branch snaps and John falls into the water fully clothed. John emerges out of the water with a remote expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Awesome.  26 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron sits in the chair, as his daughters lie on the hospital bed with Sally. They all watch a kids TV show. Stacey enters the room, followed by Reverend Dan. Ron looks

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. There you are.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Hey, mom.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: I've been looking all over for you. What are you guys doing? Why didn’t you go to school today?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Dad brought us here instead.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: No one called me. I was worried sick.

dialogues.speaker: MATILDA
dialogues.text: Grandma’s got a tumor the size of basketball in her head.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’s the size of a soft ball actually.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. Sally, I’m so sorry. at Reverend Dan.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What is he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: You can’t take our kids out of school without calling me, Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: My mom is sick.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you still should have called.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (whispers ) But...she could die any minute.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I can hear you, Ron. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you for a second? Alone? Ron follows his ex-wife out of the room. He gives Reverend Dan a deathly glare as he walks past him.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAN
dialogues.text: Anyone want to pray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacey waits until she is out of the children’s earshot.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? You’re scaring the girls. Not to mention your mom.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Come on, Ron. Don’t be a child. Stacey sighs.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What did you bring him here for?

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: I was worried. He comforted me.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So, you guys serious or...

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Ron. We've been divorced for over two years.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. So?

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: So, it was your idea to get divorced in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Well...what if I wanted to change my mind?

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Change your mind? Change your mind about what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me??

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: I don’t even know what to say to that.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (very vulnerable) I'm lonely. I just lost my job. I got no one to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: +... And who’s to blame for that?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Stacey, I just wasn’t ready.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Well, life doesn’t wait Ron. Stacey shakes her head and walks past Ron as she goes into Sally’s hospital room to collect the girls. Ron stands in the hallway alone reeling... then finally follows behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Dan holds Sally and the youngest daughter’s hands in a prayer circle.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hey, get your hands off my family you pervert. Everyone stops praying and looks at Ron.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAN
dialogues.text: I was just offering your mother a little prayer.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, who asked you?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Come on, girls. We’re leaving. The girls kiss their grandmother goodbye and leave the room with their mom.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (whispers to Dan) If I were you I’d pray for me--

dialogues.speaker: REVREND DAN
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Wait. You didn’t let me finish. I was going to say--

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Good bye, Ron. Stacey and kids leave with Reverend Dan.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: ...-for me not to kick your--Oh, damn it! A beat later John enters the room carrying a dripping JC Penny bag. He wears a T-shirt with a funky graphic on it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, what's going on? Why does everyone look so upset?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (upbeat) No one’s upset. Ron wipes away a tear. John looks at the cat scan on the wall monitor.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, look, I was thinking we should ask Dr. Fong about this procedure. I want to know more about the risks involved with removing the tumor.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I don’t want to know anything about that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He’s going to be operating on your brain. If we’re not going to get a second opinion we should at least find out more about what he plans to do. His level of experience. Stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I trust him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But you don’t even know him.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Asian people are very hard workers.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. And they have tiny hands which helps in surgery. John doesn’t know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I just... think we should be prepared.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That's fine, John. Ask him whatever you want. Just leave me out of it, okay? John sees how scared his mother is. He stops pressing the subject. Ron looks at John.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Is that my shirt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Ron walk up to a nurse’s desk in the neurology department.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ron and John Hollar for Dr. Fong, please.

dialogues.speaker: NEUROLOGY NURSE
dialogues.text: Have a seat. Dr. Fong will be right with you. John and Ron sit in a waiting room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hey, look, I know you think you’re hot shit ever since you moved to New York but don’t be an asshole, okay? This guy holds mom’s life in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? I don’t think I’m hot shit. What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Sure you do. That’s why you never call. You think you’re better than us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I told you I don’t like talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You used to call Gwen all the time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She was my girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? Understand what?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You're jealous.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Why would I be jealous? You live in mom and dad’s basement.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You got kind of ignored growing up. I was the one that everyone thought had promise. You were just kind of a spaz. And mom and dad were so busy starting that business they never really had any time for you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I hate plumbing supplies.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You resent me, don’t you? You resent all of us. That’s why you moved so far away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I moved to New York because there’s nothing to do here. And besides, it’s not like mom and dad’s attention really helped you out that much. I was probably better off with them not around.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No one’s better off without their parents around. John gives Ron a strange look. His brother has hit a nerve. INT.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatever. I don’t care, either. Just don’t offend this guy, okay? DR. FONG’S OFFICE. DAY. 30 John and Ron are seated in front of Dr. Fong’s desk. Dr. Fong is in scrubs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: I have to be in surgery in a few minutes, but, how can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, my brother and I were just wondering if you could tell us a little more about this procedure you want our mother to have. Will you actually be able to remove all of the tumor--

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I wasn’t wondering. I trust you. My mom and dad trust you, too.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. We love Asian people.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Ah. That’s...nice.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I use to take karate as a kid. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dr. Fong looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The instructor was actually black but I’m pretty sure he’d spent some time in China.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Mmm, well.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Mmm. What martial art do you do?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: None. Ron is blown away!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Getting back to the tumor--

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: --I guess you’re probably pretty busy with brain surgery and whatnot.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FONG
dialogues.text: Yeah. Pretty busy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ron, let’s--

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Does it help to have small hands? Dr. Fong looks at his hands. He’s very insulted. John looks at Ron.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Please shut up.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of Hollar house. A young girl drives by on a bike and throws a news paper.  31 32 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don sits in a bank office. He looks very uncomfortable. An older man, Don’s contemporary, comes back to his desk with a packet of papers.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: Hmm... Now, it says here you filed for your third loan three months ago?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah, things are tough.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: Mmm. Mmm. Look, Don, I don’t see how I can get them to give you another loan given your current financial status.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Business is picking up. I’m going to get a new salesman to drum up more business soon. I just need to cover payroll for the next month or so.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: I’m-- I’m sorry, Don.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I’m on the chamber of commerce and I can’t even take my kids out to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: I wish there was something I could do.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Hey, look here, you prick. I gave my life to this business. I gave my life to it. It’s not supposed to be like this.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Don.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: --. You heard Sally is sick.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: --. I’m very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don drives down the street looking very troubled. He passes the Liquor Barn, a midwestern liquor wholesaler. Don pulls into the parking lot.  33 34 35 36 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don walks past a young Mexican American man, wearing an apron, stocking shelves and up to an older woman behind the cash register. While she finishes with another customer Don finds himself staring off at their selection of expensive scotch behind the counter. Cashier snaps him out of it with:

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m here about your help wanted sign.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: You over 21?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Unfortunately.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Need to see ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron walks past his mother’s bathroom and stops... then slowly walks in. Nothing has been touched since Sally suffered her seizure on the floor. The sight of a broken mirror and Sally’s curling iron on the floor effects Ron. He picks up the curling iron and places it on the bathroom counter. He catches himself in the mirror. He does not like what he sees. Ron looks at his face, then sees grey hairs in his beard. His face drops.  37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron does some stretching on the front lawn of his parents house. He wears an old track suit... It says ‘HOLLAR’ on the arm. He starts to jog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow along with Ron as he runs. He stops, winded. After a long beat... he continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Sally’s room, a new patient has been brought in as Sally’s roommate. This is LaTisha an African American woman in her 60’s. Sally, John and LaTisha watch a Tyler Perry movie on the hospital television. Don walks into the hospital room. He looks very tired.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Hey, honey! How was work.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (confused) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: This is my new roomate, LaTifa!

dialogues.speaker: LATISHA
dialogues.text: LaTisha.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: LATISHA
dialogues.text: You, too. Don walks over to Sally and John. He hands John a bottle of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Here. This is for you. John looks at the bottle. It is good whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Whiskey?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It’s good stuff. Or so I’m told. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s the occasion?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just wanted to get you something.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (a little confused) Thanks, Dad. John’s cellphone rings he picks it up and goes to the corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: How you holding up, chief?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Great. Just watching a movie with LaTiii-- Sally looks to LaTisha unsure of the name again.

dialogues.speaker: LATISHA
dialogues.text: Sha.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What are you watching?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Madusa Goes to Jail.

dialogues.speaker: LATISHA
dialogues.text: (corrects) Madea.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’s a riot. Don nods his head. He sits down and watches with Sally. John hangs up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That was Ron. He needs me to go pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: At a gas station in Bristol.  39 40 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron sits next to a phone booth outside a small appliance store in the middle of nowhere. He is still wearing his high school track suit. He is covered in sweat. John pulls into the gas station. He opens the passenger door. Ron gets inside the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron and John drive in silence. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What were you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I went for a run.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s like twenty miles from the house.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I need to start running again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You can’t do it all in one day.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m so thirsty... You have any water?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Well, I need something to drink. You don’t have anything in here?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Dad gave me a bottle of whiskey. Ron thinks about this for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s in the backseat. Ron digs through the backseat. He finds the bottle. He opens it, takes a sniff. Ron takes a huge drink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: This is good.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Ron?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m fine. Ron takes another swig of whiskey. It goes straight to his head. He starts to weep.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m so alone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You're not alone. You have your kids.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: They hate me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, they don’t hate you.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: How would you know? John thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I live with my parents. I don’t have a job. I haven’t had sex in almost four years.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You haven't had sex in four years? Ron nods with shame.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It's not that big a deal. I don’t think mom and dad have had sex in a lot longer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I really don’t want to think about any of you guys having sex. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You don’t really care about me, do you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Of course, I do. You’re my brother.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: We've never been that close.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, there’s an age difference.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: We're like two only children.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: With brothers.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I bet you wouldn’t even talk to me if we didn’t know each other.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t usually talk to people I don’t know. So.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. If we were strangers at a bar or something and I came up to you and tried to start a conversation. I bet you would just blow me off, wouldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Let’s try it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Let’s pretend we’re strangers. Try starting a conversation with me. Ron thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Right now?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ron takes Ron feels 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a swig of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You want a drink or...?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I’m not into gays. like an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Asshole.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Come on, Ron. I was just kidding around.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It's easy for you. You got a whole life apart from this shit. A beautiful girlfriend. A baby on the way.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, you had all that, too, at one point.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So...what happened?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I guess I just...didn’t want to be a dad. This troubles John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do you now? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That doesn’t really matter. Those kids are mine regardless.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's a depressing answer.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hey, look, I love them more than anything else in this world. All I want is for them to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: They’1l be happy if you’re happy.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: And that’s why we’re all screwed. 41 EXT. HOUSE. DAY. 4l John stands at the front door of a small ranch house. He knocks on the door. He holds a bouquet of wild flowers in his hands. He takes a deep breath. Jason opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Oh. Hey. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You invited me over for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. That’s right. Jason looks at the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those for Gwen?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No...well...yes....they’re for both of you. John gives them to Jason. Jason smells them.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: We don’t like flowers.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Come in. Gwen’s just getting ready. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l 42 60. CONTINUED: 4l John walks inside the house. Jason throws the flowers onto the front lawn. INT. LIVING ROOM, GWEN AND JASON’S HOUSE. DAY. 42 A screaming baby sits in a bassinet in the middle of the living room. John looks at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Is this your...baby?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No, it’s just a decoy. We keep the real kid in the refrigerator John doesn’t know how to take this.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s the name?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Quinn.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He’s cute.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She's a girl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: We named her after Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman. (beat) It seemed like a funny idea at the time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah. No. It’s...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You want a beer?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sure. John looks at the screaming baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is she okay? Jason walks towards the kitchen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s fine. Crying is healthy for kids. Good for their lungs. John is alone with the screaming baby. He kneels down to say hello.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, baby. Hey, little girl. How are you? You okay? The baby stops crying and gives John a funny look. John smiles at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
